title: SME Exit Readiness Assessment
description: Assess your organisation's readiness for exit across 6 critical domains. Transparency over perfection - understanding your gaps is more valuable than hiding them. Complete in 30-60 minutes.

levels.name: Incomplete
levels.description: Significant gaps, ad hoc or unknown

questions.text: How is accounting managed?
questions.plainSummary: Are your financial records complete, accurate, and ready for external review?
explanations: No formal bookkeeping; records are incomplete or missing.
Basic bookkeeping exists but accounts are unaudited and may have gaps.
Accounts are prepared regularly; accountant-prepared accounts available for recent years.
Audited accounts current; all statutory filings up to date; records audit-ready.
Full audit trail; potentially vendor DD pack prepared; all financial records immediately accessible.

questions.text: How robust are management accounts and financial reporting?
questions.plainSummary: Do you produce regular internal financial reports that show how the business is performing?
explanations: No regular management accounts; financial visibility is minimal.
Ad hoc management reports produced; limited detail on P&L and balance sheet.
Monthly management accounts produced; clear P&L and balance sheet reporting.
Comprehensive monthly reporting with variance analysis and forecasts.
Real-time financial dashboards; integrated planning and scenario modeling.

questions.text: Is EBITDA and profitability measured, normalised, and documented for review?
questions.plainSummary: Do you know your real operating profit, with unusual or one-off items explained?
explanations: EBITDA not calculated or understood; profitability unclear.
EBITDA calculated informally; adjustments not documented.
EBITDA normalised with documented adjustments for one-offs and owner costs.
Normalised EBITDA defensible with detailed add-back schedule; auditor reviewed.
Quality of earnings analysis complete; EBITDA bridge prepared for buyers.

questions.text: How is revenue recognized and are policies compliant with accounting standards?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have clear, consistent rules for when income counts as earned?
explanations: Revenue recognition is ad hoc or inconsistent; no clear policies.
Basic revenue recognition applied; not fully compliant with standards.
Revenue policies documented and consistent with accounting standards.
Revenue recognition fully compliant; policies reviewed by auditors annually.
Revenue recognition sophisticated (multi-element, subscriptions); fully disclosed.

questions.text: Are Working capital requirements understood and optimised with clear processes?
questions.plainSummary: Do you manage cash flow by tracking what customers owe you, what you owe suppliers, and stock levels?
explanations: Working capital not monitored; cash flow often unpredictable.
Basic tracking of debtors/creditors; working capital requirements unclear.
Working capital understood; debtors, creditors, stock managed with clear processes.
Working capital optimised; forecasting models in place; cash conversion tracked.
Working capital locked-box ready; daily visibility; optimised for transaction.

questions.text: Is tax compliance current with filings, clearances, and liabilities documented?
questions.plainSummary: Are all your tax returns filed on time with no outstanding disputes or unknown liabilities?
explanations: Tax compliance uncertain; filings may be overdue or incomplete.
Tax returns filed but not all clearances obtained; liabilities may exist.
Tax compliance current; major clearances obtained; liabilities quantified.
All tax clearances current; no disputes; comprehensive tax DD pack prepared.
Proactive tax planning; clearances pre-obtained; no material tax risk.

questions.text: Is corporate structure clear with clean ownership, updated registers, and filed returns?
questions.plainSummary: Is it clear who owns the business, and are all official company records up to date?
explanations: Corporate structure unclear; registers out of date; filings overdue.
Basic structure understood; some registers updated; filings mostly current.
Clean corporate structure; registers complete; all filings current.
Corporate structure optimised for exit; all documentation audit-ready.
Full legal DD pack prepared; corporate structure verified by external counsel.

questions.text: Are statutory books complete with board minutes, resolutions, and governance documentation?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have proper records of board meetings and major decisions?
explanations: Statutory books incomplete; board minutes missing or not maintained.
Some statutory records exist but gaps in board minutes and resolutions.
Statutory books substantially complete with regular board minutes.
All statutory books current; comprehensive governance documentation in place.
Institutional-grade statutory records; legal VDD confirms completeness.

questions.text: Are material contracts identified, documented, and assignable?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have copies of all important contracts, and can they be transferred to a new owner?
explanations: Material contracts not identified or documented; terms unclear.
Some contracts documented but not comprehensive; assignability unknown.
Material contracts identified and documented; assignability reviewed.
All material contracts cataloged with assignability confirmed; change of control reviewed.
Full contracts schedule in legal DD pack; all consents obtained or waived.

questions.text: Is Intellectual Property owned by the company with clear chain of title and registrations?
questions.plainSummary: Does the company (not individuals) own all trademarks, patents, software, and creative works?
explanations: IP ownership unclear; no registrations or assignments documented.
Some IP documented but chain of title unclear; employee assignments missing.
Core IP owned by company; registrations current; employee assignments in place.
All IP ownership verified; full chain of title documented; no infringement risk.
IP DD pack complete; freedom to operate confirmed; all rights assigned to company.

questions.text: Is property and asset ownership documented with leases, licenses, and equipment properly recorded?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have records of all property, equipment, and lease agreements?
explanations: Property and assets undocumented; leases or licenses may be missing.
Some property records exist but incomplete; lease terms not fully understood.
Property and assets documented; leases and equipment schedules current.
All property rights confirmed; leases assignable; asset register complete.
Full property DD pack; all consents obtained; no title or lease issues.

questions.text: Are litigation and disputes resolved or quantified?
questions.plainSummary: Are there any ongoing or potential lawsuits, and do you know the financial exposure?
explanations: Litigation risk unknown; disputes or claims may be undisclosed.
Some litigation known but not all resolved or quantified.
Material litigation resolved or quantified; no undisclosed claims.
No material litigation; all disputes resolved; comprehensive legal clearance.
Full litigation clearance confirmed by external counsel; W&I insurance viable.

questions.text: How diversified is the customer base?
questions.plainSummary: How much of your revenue depends on your biggest customers?
explanations: High customer concentration; top customer >30% of revenue.
Top customer 20-30% of revenue; concentration risk recognised.
Top customer <20% of revenue; diversified customer base.
Top customer <15% of revenue; well-diversified across multiple customers.
Highly diversified; no customer >10% of revenue; low concentration risk.

questions.text: How predictable is revenue?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have repeat customers, subscriptions, or long-term contracts that make income predictable?
explanations: Revenue is project-based or one-off; minimal predictability.
Some repeat customers but revenue not contracted or recurring.
Recurring or repeat revenue model; some contracted revenue.
Majority of revenue recurring or contracted; high predictability.
Subscription or long-term contracts; revenue highly predictable and growing.

questions.text: How well are customer retention and churn tracked?
questions.plainSummary: Do you know how many customers stay with you versus leave, and why?
explanations: Customer retention not tracked; churn unknown.
Some customer tracking but retention and churn not measured consistently.
Retention and churn tracked; evidence of loyalty and repeat business.
Low churn (<15%); retention metrics tracked; customer lifetime value understood.
Excellent retention (<10% churn); high LTV; evidence of customer advocacy.

questions.text: Are sales pipeline and funnel managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you track potential sales opportunities and how likely they are to close?
explanations: No sales pipeline; future revenue visibility is minimal.
Ad hoc sales tracking; pipeline exists but not systematically managed.
Sales pipeline and funnel managed; visibility of future opportunities.
CRM system in place; pipeline coverage >3x quota; conversion rates tracked.
Sophisticated sales forecasting; pipeline analytics; predictive revenue modeling.

questions.text: Are market position and competitive advantage understood and defensible?
questions.plainSummary: Can you explain what makes your business different and why customers choose you over competitors?
explanations: Market position unclear; competitive advantage not articulated.
Some understanding of market but competitive position not well defined.
Market position understood; competitive advantage identified and documented.
Strong market position evidenced; differentiation clear; sustainable competitive advantage.
Market leader or clear niche dominance; competitive moat defensible and growing.

questions.text: Is customer satisfaction measured?
questions.plainSummary: Do you regularly ask customers how happy they are and track the results?
explanations: Customer satisfaction not measured; feedback is anecdotal.
Some customer feedback collected but not systematically measured.
Customer satisfaction tracked; NPS or similar metric measured.
High customer satisfaction (NPS >30); strong relationships evidenced.
Excellent NPS (>50); customer references and case studies prepared; advocacy program.

questions.text: Are business processes documented?
questions.plainSummary: Could someone new run your business by following written procedures, without relying on you?
explanations: Core processes undocumented; tribal knowledge; high founder dependency.
Some processes documented but inconsistent; significant founder involvement required.
Core processes documented in SOPs; business can operate with reduced founder input.
All processes documented and followed; minimal founder dependency in daily operations.
Fully systematised operations; founder can step back; processes optimised for scale.

questions.text: Is IT infrastructure resilient with disaster recovery and business continuity plans?
questions.plainSummary: If your computer systems failed, could you recover quickly and keep the business running?
explanations: IT systems ad hoc; no disaster recovery or business continuity planning.
Basic IT systems; some backups but no tested DR plan.
IT infrastructure documented; backups automated; basic DR plan in place.
Comprehensive IT documentation; DR plan tested annually; business continuity confirmed.
Institutional-grade IT; cloud-native; automated failover; full operational resilience.

questions.text: Is supply chain managed with key suppliers identified and contingency plans in place?
questions.plainSummary: Do you know your critical suppliers and have backup options if they fail?
explanations: Supply chain undocumented; single-source dependencies; no contingency.
Some supplier documentation but dependencies not managed; contingency unclear.
Key suppliers identified; some dual-sourcing; basic supplier management.
Supply chain documented; dual-sourcing for critical inputs; supplier contracts current.
Optimised supply chain; supplier risk managed; full contingency planning; SRM programme.

questions.text: Are operational KPIs tracked?
questions.plainSummary: Do you measure and monitor key performance numbers for your operations?
explanations: Operational KPIs not tracked; performance visibility is minimal.
Some metrics tracked informally; no systematic reporting.
Key operational metrics tracked; regular reporting to management.
Comprehensive KPI dashboards; metrics aligned to business goals; benchmarked.
Real-time operational analytics; predictive insights; continuous improvement culture.

questions.text: Is quality management implemented formally?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have systematic processes to ensure consistent quality of products or services?
explanations: Quality management is informal; no systematic QA processes.
Basic quality checks but no formal QA system; issues often reactive.
Quality management processes documented; regular QA reviews.
Formal QA/QC program; ISO9001 or equivalent; systematic quality tracking.
Continuous quality improvement; Six Sigma or Lean; quality excellence embedded.

questions.text: How scalable are operations to support growth?
questions.plainSummary: Could your business handle significantly more customers without major changes?
explanations: Growth capacity unclear; scalability not demonstrated.
Some capacity for growth but constraints not identified or planned for.
Growth capacity understood; infrastructure can support 2x revenue growth.
Scalability demonstrated; systems and processes can support 3-5x growth.
Highly scalable platform; growth capacity >5x; infrastructure investment-ready.

questions.text: Are employment contracts in place?
questions.plainSummary: Does every employee have a proper written contract covering their role and terms?
explanations: No employment contracts or contracts missing key terms.
Basic employment contracts in place but some gaps or inconsistencies.
All employees have proper contracts; terms compliant with employment law.
Comprehensive employment contracts; reviewed by legal; fully compliant.
Institutional-grade employment documentation; all contracts audit-ready.

questions.text: Is the organisation structure defined with clear roles and responsibilities?
questions.plainSummary: Is there a clear organisation chart showing who does what and who reports to whom?
explanations: Org structure unclear; roles and reporting lines undefined.
Basic org chart exists but roles not well defined; some ambiguity.
Org structure documented; roles and responsibilities clear.
Comprehensive org chart; role clarity; succession planning for key roles.
Sophisticated org design; talent development plans; leadership pipeline.

questions.text: How reliant is the business on key individuals?
questions.plainSummary: Could the business continue successfully if the owner or key people left?
explanations: High key person risk; business depends on founder or 1-2 individuals.
Some key person dependency managed but significant risk remains.
Key person risk identified; retention plans and succession in place.
Low key person risk; management depth; team can operate without founder.
No key person risk; institutional management team; succession plans for all roles.

questions.text: Are HR policies and procedures documented and communicated?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have a staff handbook covering policies like holidays, sickness, and conduct?
explanations: No HR policies; employee handbook does not exist.
Basic HR policies exist but not comprehensive or consistently applied.
Employee handbook and HR policies documented and communicated.
Comprehensive HR policies; performance reviews; compensation framework.
Institutional-grade HR; full policy suite; regular reviews; benchmarked compensation.

questions.text: How is staff retention managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you track staff turnover and have plans to keep your best people?
explanations: High turnover or flight risk not identified; retention uncertain.
Some turnover tracking but retention risks not systematically managed.
Turnover tracked; retention plans for key employees; low voluntary attrition.
Low turnover (<15%); retention incentives in place; employee satisfaction high.
Excellent retention (<10%); LTIP or equity plans; culture of loyalty and engagement.

questions.text: How is staff training and development managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you invest in training and helping employees develop their skills?
explanations: Training and development is ad hoc; skills gaps not identified.
Some training provided but not systematic; development plans informal.
Training programs in place; skills development tracked.
Comprehensive L&D program; skills framework; training aligned to business needs.
Continuous learning culture; leadership development; high engagement in training.

questions.text: Is Health and Safety understood and managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have proper health and safety policies, risk assessments, and incident tracking?
explanations: H&S compliance uncertain; no risk assessments or incident reporting.
Basic H&S awareness but not systematic; some policies exist.
H&S risk assessments current; policies documented; incidents tracked.
Comprehensive H&S program; regular audits; training current; low incident rate.
H&S excellence; certifications (ISO45001); zero harm culture; proactive risk management.

questions.text: How is data protection (GDPR/privacy) compliance managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you comply with data protection laws and have a privacy policy?
explanations: GDPR/data protection compliance uncertain; no privacy policy or data mapping.
Basic data protection awareness but gaps in compliance; policies incomplete.
GDPR baseline compliance; privacy policy in place; data mapping complete.
Strong data protection; DPO appointed (if required); DPIA process; regular reviews.
Privacy by design; ISO27001 or equivalent; full data governance; privacy-enhancing tech.

questions.text: Are cyber security controls implemented?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have measures to protect against hackers, viruses, and data breaches?
explanations: Cyber security is minimal; no systematic controls or monitoring.
Basic cyber security (firewalls, AV) but no systematic risk management.
Cyber security controls in place; penetration testing; incident response plan.
Comprehensive cyber security program; SOC or managed security; regular testing.
Institutional-grade security; ISO27001; threat intelligence; continuous monitoring.

questions.text: Is environmental impact managed?
questions.plainSummary: Do you track and work to reduce your business's environmental footprint?
explanations: Environmental impact unknown; no environmental policies.
Some environmental awareness but no systematic management.
Environmental policies documented; basic compliance with regulations.
Environmental management system (ISO14001 or equivalent); impact measured and reduced.
Environmental excellence; carbon neutral or net zero commitment; ESG reporting.

questions.text: Is risk management formalised with a risk register and mitigation plans?
questions.plainSummary: Do you keep a list of business risks and have plans to address them?
explanations: Risk management is reactive; no risk register or systematic process.
Some risks identified informally but not systematically managed.
Risk register maintained; key risks identified and mitigated.
Comprehensive risk framework; risks reviewed regularly; board oversight.
Enterprise risk management; quantitative risk modeling; integrated into strategy.

questions.text: Is insurance coverage appropriate for business risks?
questions.plainSummary: Do you have the right insurance policies covering all major business risks?
explanations: Business insurance is minimal or gaps exist; coverage uncertain.
Basic insurance (liability, property) but coverage gaps may exist.
Appropriate insurance coverage; key risks insured; policies current.
Comprehensive insurance; D&O, professional indemnity, cyber; limits appropriate.
Institutional-grade insurance; W&I insurance viable; all material risks covered.

glossary.definition: Earnings Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortisation — a measure of operating profit before accounting adjustments. It shows how much money the business makes from its core operations.
A document that explains how you get from reported profit to adjusted EBITDA, showing each adjustment made and why. Buyers use this to understand and verify the 'real' profit.
Adjusted to remove one-off or unusual items that don't reflect normal business performance, such as a large one-time contract or exceptional legal costs.

Due Diligence Pack — a comprehensive set of documents prepared for potential buyers. These are typically produced by independent specialist firms who are liable for accuracy, making them a significant investment but providing credibility and speed to transactions.

Vendor Due Diligence Pack — documents independently prepared by specialist advisers commissioned by the seller. The advisers are professionally liable for the accuracy of their findings, which gives buyers confidence. This is typically a significant investment (£50k-£200k+) but speeds up sales and can improve deal certainty.

Tax Due Diligence Pack — specialist tax analysis prepared by independent tax advisers who are liable for their findings. Covers corporation tax, VAT, PAYE, and any tax risks. A significant investment but provides buyer confidence on tax matters.

Legal Due Diligence Pack — comprehensive legal review independently prepared by specialist solicitors who are professionally liable for their findings. Covers corporate structure, contracts, IP, property, litigation, and compliance. A significant investment but essential for larger transactions.

Legal Vendor Due Diligence — independent legal review commissioned by the seller and prepared by specialist solicitors who are professionally liable for accuracy. Focuses specifically on legal matters: corporate structure, contracts, IP, employment, and compliance. A significant investment but speeds up transactions.
Property Due Diligence Pack — independent review of property matters prepared by specialist surveyors or property lawyers. Covers title, leases, planning, environmental issues, and property rights.
Intellectual Property Due Diligence Pack — independent review of IP matters prepared by specialist IP lawyers. Covers ownership, registrations, freedom to operate, and infringement risks.
A transaction mechanism where accounts are frozen at a specific date, with no value (cash, dividends) leaving the business after that point until completion.
When business ownership transfers to a new party. Some contracts require consent or may terminate when this happens.
A complete record of transactions and changes that allows someone to trace how figures were calculated and verify their accuracy.

Financial statements that have been independently verified by a registered auditor. The auditor checks the figures are accurate and comply with accounting standards, providing assurance to buyers and lenders.
Financial information that has been examined by an independent auditor. This provides external validation that the figures are accurate and prepared according to proper accounting standards.
Official documents that must be filed with government bodies like Companies House, including annual accounts and confirmation statements.
A list of costs that are added back to profit to show the 'true' earnings, such as owner salary above market rate or personal expenses run through the business.
An analysis that examines whether reported profits are sustainable, recurring, and from genuine business operations rather than one-off items.
The cash tied up in day-to-day operations — money owed by customers minus money owed to suppliers, plus stock. It's the fuel that keeps the business running.
How efficiently the business turns profits into actual cash. A business might be profitable on paper but struggle if customers pay slowly.
Official confirmation from HMRC that specific transactions or arrangements are acceptable and won't result in unexpected tax bills.
How the business is legally organised — the companies, subsidiaries, and shareholdings that make up the group.
Official company records required by law, including the register of members (shareholders), directors, and charges (secured loans).
Written records of decisions made at board meetings. These provide evidence that proper governance was followed.
Formal decisions made by directors or shareholders, often required for significant actions like issuing shares or changing the company's articles.
Important agreements that significantly affect the business — typically large customer contracts, supplier agreements, or key partnerships.
Whether a contract can be transferred to a new owner. Some contracts require the other party's consent before they can be assigned.
Whether a contract can be transferred to a new owner. Some contracts require the other party's consent before they can be assigned.
The documented history of ownership for intellectual property, proving the company legitimately owns what it claims to own.
Confirmation that the business's products or services don't infringe on others' patents, trademarks, or copyrights.
Warranty and Indemnity insurance — covers the buyer if the seller's promises about the business turn out to be wrong. It can make deals smoother.
Key Performance Indicators — the most important numbers that show how well the business is performing, like sales growth, profit margins, or customer retention.
Standard Operating Procedures — written instructions for how to perform routine tasks consistently, so the business doesn't rely on individuals' knowledge.
Disaster Recovery plan — documented steps to restore IT systems and data after a major incident like a fire, flood, or cyber attack.
Supplier Relationship Management — systematic processes for evaluating, managing, and developing relationships with key suppliers.
Long-Term Incentive Plan — a scheme that rewards employees (usually senior staff) based on the company's long-term performance, often through shares or bonuses.
Net Promoter Score — a customer satisfaction metric based on how likely customers are to recommend you. Scores range from -100 to +100; above 50 is excellent.
Lifetime Value — the total revenue you expect from a customer over the entire time they do business with you.
The rate at which customers stop doing business with you. Lower churn means customers stay longer and are worth more.
Data Protection Impact Assessment — a process to identify and minimise privacy risks when handling personal data, required by GDPR for high-risk processing.
Data Protection Officer — a person responsible for overseeing data protection compliance. Required for some organisations under GDPR.
General Data Protection Regulation — UK and EU law governing how organisations collect, store, and use personal data. Non-compliance can result in significant fines.
Profit and Loss statement — a financial report showing revenue, costs, and profit over a period. Also called an income statement. Shows whether the business is making or losing money.
Comparing actual financial results to budgets or forecasts and explaining the differences. Shows whether the business is performing as expected and why.
Customer Relationship Management — software and processes for tracking interactions with customers and prospects. Examples include Salesforce, HubSpot, and Pipedrive.
Quality Assurance system — formal processes and checks to ensure products or services meet defined standards consistently. May include testing, inspections, and documentation.
An international standard for quality management systems. Certification shows the business has consistent processes for delivering quality products or services.
An international standard for quality management systems. Certification shows the business has consistent processes for delivering quality products or services.
An international standard for environmental management systems. Certification shows the business systematically manages its environmental impact.
An international standard for environmental management systems. Certification shows the business systematically manages its environmental impact.
An international standard for information security management. Certification shows the business has robust processes to protect sensitive data.
An international standard for information security management. Certification shows the business has robust processes to protect sensitive data.
An international standard for occupational health and safety management. Certification shows the business systematically protects worker wellbeing.
An international standard for occupational health and safety management. Certification shows the business systematically protects worker wellbeing.
Learning and Development — the function responsible for employee training, skills development, and career growth programmes within an organisation.
Antivirus software — programs that detect and remove malicious software (malware) from computers. A basic component of cyber security.
Security Operations Centre — a team (internal or outsourced) that monitors systems 24/7 for security threats and responds to incidents. Provides continuous cyber security protection.
Directors and Officers — refers to the leadership team of a company. D&O insurance protects them personally against claims arising from their business decisions.
A methodology for improving processes by reducing defects and variability. Organisations using it typically have highly consistent, efficient operations.
A methodology focused on eliminating waste and maximising value. Lean organisations tend to be efficient with minimal unnecessary steps or inventory.
Care Quality Commission — the independent regulator of health and social care in England. CQC ratings (Outstanding to Inadequate) significantly affect healthcare business value.
Due Diligence — the investigation a buyer conducts before purchasing a business, examining finances, legal matters, operations, and risks.

Vendor Due Diligence — independent due diligence commissioned by the seller and prepared by specialist advisers who are professionally liable for accuracy. A significant investment but speeds up sales and improves deal certainty.
Mergers and Acquisitions — the process of combining companies (merger) or one company buying another (acquisition).
Income that repeats regularly, such as subscriptions, retainers, or maintenance contracts. Buyers value this highly because it's predictable.
The collection of potential sales opportunities being worked on at various stages, from initial contact to near-closing.
When the business relies heavily on the owner's personal relationships, knowledge, or involvement. High dependency reduces business value.
The danger that losing one critical individual (founder, key salesperson, technical expert) could seriously harm the business.
Preparing for key people to leave by identifying and developing their potential replacements in advance.
A documented list of identified risks, their likelihood, potential impact, and the actions being taken to manage them.
Directors and Officers insurance — protects company leaders personally against claims arising from their decisions and actions as directors.
Insurance that covers claims from clients alleging your professional advice or services caused them financial loss.
